number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
												Definitely happy that I didn't pay full price for this. The atmosphere is done really well. There's always a feeling of unease, and when stuff starts happening around you it's pretty insane and unsettling, which is great. However, I feel like without the guides I found online, I wouldn't have been able to figure out a lot of what was supposed to be done because some of the tasks are so convoluted. The story itself isn't that bad, but it i very predictable and when the character starts to piece it together, they kind of play stupid and it's frustrating being 5 steps ahead of the character. I think the game looks pretty, and that was one of the reasons I wanted it, and it will be more enjoyable to replay and try to get different endings now that I have a better idea of what to do. There is some replay value to it, because there are several different endings you can get, but other than trying for different endings, which some people might not try to do, there isn't replay value. My biggest complaint though, is that if you play it on Windows, you have to register or sign in to a Kalypso account. Every. Single. Time. You. Launch it. It's a minor annoyance the first timme. After the second time it gets old. It's bad enough having to set up an account, but it's made worse by needing to log in to it every time you go to play. Only the people who play it on Windows have to sign in to Kalypso though, so if you don't play on windows, that won't affect you. Overall, I wouldn't recommend the game, especially at full price, unless you like confusing tasks and predictable stories.

content:
Posted: September 15, 2014
												I've invested a little less than half an hour into this game after it became abundantly clear that this is not something I can enjoy. I love a good adventure game and after playing Amnesia, I've bought this game -thankfully on a sale- to satisfy my urge for more scary, adventure-y goodness.  Unfortunately I was disappointed.The game starts with asking you to create a Kalypso user account (which is essentially an extra layer of unneccesary DRM); something we don't need nor will probably ever use. It is noted on the Store page for the title however, so buyers beware.  In the game, your character moves in a fashion that I could only call unnatural. I don't know if it is due to the FOV or something else, but I felt literally nauseated after playing for 15 minutes. I normally don't get motion sickness from first-person games, especially ones with a relatively slower movement speed, like this one. But since I've spent very little time with the title I can't tell if its a fluke or not. The user interface is horrible. It simply is badly designed, so much so that I had to check if it was a console port or something(It isn't). It is completely counter-intuitive, hard to navigate and use. In an adventure game, this is unacceptable. The options menu is very barebones, it feels like the developers made it as an afterthought, quite reminiscent of a bad port instead of the PC exclusive title that we have.The puzzles are very contrived and illogical(unlike say, Monkey Island, it really doesn't have any redeeming qualities, such as being humorous). By the time I managed to go into the house(you start outside at the beggining) I've already lost my interest in the game.  I don't care  if the game opens up or gets very scary afterwards, I simply didn't see any reason to stick with it any longer. The game looks pretty and it ran on my machine smoothly without any problems. I haven't encountered any bugs. The sound assets used were quite good. All in all, the game might get better later on, for all I know. But I didn't want to struggle with the bad UI and the uninspired puzzles to get to the meat. I uninstalled the title immediately after exiting it. I would recommend the prospective buyer to watch a gameplay video so that they can decide if the problems I report are relevant to them.If you're a fan of the genre, you might want to pick it up at a sale. But I can not, in good conscience, recommend this game.

Posted: January 27, 2014
												I loved adventure games back in the old days of PC. I liked solving puzzles and I also like horror stories.I've attempted to play Anna three times, quite desperate to get into it. In the end, I found myself not satisfied in any category - the gameplay is boring, the horror isn't exciting and I very quickly lose the drive to solve any of the puzzles. I'd love to see the story until the end, but I know I'll just find myself reading the guide just to get through it, and there's no fun in that.Personally not one I'd recommend.

												A ridiculous waste of time. A friend and myself both bought the game thinking that it would be an enoyable mystery/horror game, however that proved to be very, very wrong. The game does not provide a sense of "chilling" and is by no means "horrific", what it is however is a gigantic group of puzzles that make so sense whatsoever, forcing the player to click around randomly until they are lucky enough to somehow move forward through the game.I am yet to try the "extended edition" as my first playthrough was incredibly mind numbingly boring.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
												I don't even know where to begin with this wretched title.  The physics are a fetid pile of dung, objects get caught on things that may or may not exist in the scene, the player movement is akin to shuffling about with giant magnets attached to your feet, and to top it all off it's not scary in the slightest.  For an attempted horror game, that last point is pretty important.  Scare moments are akin to things leaping out and yelling "boo" and tend to be amazingly predictable.  I found myself constantly frustrated and tired by the inability for this game to do anything but a few visuals correctly.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 29, 2014
												"I should of..." said the protagonist, at the very cheesy end. I can't advise against buying this, yet I do not recommend it either.Puzzles were not "intuitive" at all, and the game kept me telling "it does not make sense" whenever I try something that was much more logical than what I was supposed to do. At first, it was more like "Oh, I didn't see that coming", but later it turned into "Why would you even do that?" and further frustration. At the end, I was playing just to finish it. Of course, it may be just me, but let me say that I am not a newcomer to this genre.Concept was really creative, sure, but the game really suffered from the Unity engine itself, controls (especially constant misscliks resulting from bounding boxes -did I say Unity?), puzzles with no logic and no hints in-story, and lousy texturing (especially at the end). And seriously... "Should of"???Thanks for your time though, developers. Atmosphere/concept did make up for those shortcomings. On occasion...

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2013
												It has a LOT of truly scary, very good moments. I like this game, mostly. But my problem isn't with the story, or the graphics, or any of that, it's simply the fact that this game does not make clear what certain interface elements are, and it makes for a huge problem later on. Unless you're prone to save scumming, so to speak, and big into going back and forth in your save files, this is going to prove to be a problem for you, I guess that if you read this, it'd be alright too. But there's some sort of sanity meter in the form of a creepy eye in the item select screen. Now, for the first few hours of gameplay it didn't move, and I honestly thought it was decoration. But later I found that it in fact was not, and by the time I had, it'd gone down too much for me to meaningfully continue the game. If there's some way to replenish it, I haven't found it. I tried staying in light, like other games have you do, but that didn't really work, so I cannot continue playing because a cutscene draws some of my sanity meter and I instantly lose.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 3, 2014
												I like the horror elements of the game, the graphics, the music, the atmosphere, and the story. The game is very immersive and there are parts of the game that were pretty scary. But the inventory management system is a constant pain in the butt, often requiring four clicks in the items menu just to see if something works. The puzzles make absolutely no sense and as a result leave the player feeling frustrated and annoyed instead of terrified. Furthermore the incomprehensible puzzles slow your progress down to a crawl. When you're not searching the cabin inch by inch for a needed item, you're asking yourself "how in the hell is that supposed to work?"I recommend just looking up a video walkthrough and just watching that instead. You'll get the story and experience of Anna without the headaches, frustration, and guesswork needed to complete this game.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
												After signing up for the publisher's DRM within DRM, you begin what is little more than another stupid adventure game to add to the heap of stupid adventure games with illogical solutions to problems. You will never 100% this game without either a guide or the inhuman stamina to click every item on every thing until you get lucky enough to stumble upon whatever obtuse thing you were expected to figure out. The story is meandering high-context psychological thriller pretension that serves as an excuse for the developer not to come up with an actual plot. For what it's worth, Anna has sparse moments that are genuinely creepy, but those scraps don't redeem this terrible walking simulator.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2013
												Well... this game was on my wish list and I was excited to play it... but for some reason I didn't find it as engaging as I wanted too.  (Played extended edition version)This is your basic - First Person puzzle solving adventure/story board game.   I generally like those, even more because it is somewhat a scary/horror style.However after playing it a few timee for a couple of hours.  I found myself not wanting to play it.  It starts out and the outside, first floor/couple of rooms are fun and the puzzles seem somewhat logical with few moving parts.Then I went upstairs and back downstairs... I had suddenly 30 items and none of the puzzles made sense and the cryptic journal books didn't help.  After wondering around, putting on masks, melting wax, and burning gold... I didn't want to play anymore.It played well, good set up, atmosphere, and puzzles, but it ran away from my attention midway I think.  Guess it wasn't for me?  Perhaps for someone else who has more patience than I do.

content:
Posted: July 10, 2014
A Not-So-Horror Game! [KAMGUSTA's REVIEW]Game is a pretty standard point-and-click adventure in a nice 3D environment... It had a charming appeal on me so I finished it in a couple of days - all the 8 endings. There are not any combat but there a couple of scary encounters, but I won't ruin your fun describing them!Puzzles are nice and unobtrusive but they don't always make sense, so you will often have to try every item combinations to advance in the game. There is also a help system if you really don't have any clue what to do. You can die, but it really requires some efforts (and this is a plus for me!)...Music is nice and so are the special effects. I did not encounter any bug - maybe they have been fixed in the latest patch.Ok, the game is not a masterpiece, but the story is nice and the gameplay is addictive. I found it worth playing.Best played with Keyboard and MouseRecommended Buy Price < 8$Score 8/10

number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												Anna's developers seem to be operating under the assumption that modern adventure games need to return to their roots, and that the best way to do that is to reintroduce pixel hunting and hours of rubbing every item in your inventory against every other item. While there's some truth to the argument that we as gamers have become spoiled by too-obvious gameplay hints and on-screen tutorials that follow you from the first five minutes of a game all the way to the final boss, the solution is not throwing out everything we've learned about game design over the last 30 years in favor of pointlessly frustrating authenticity.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												After finishing through the "Truth" ending I felt so compelled to write a review on the game. To say the least, this gaming experience had its unforseen ups and downs. It balances out in the end, but overall it was a gaming experience I do not often have.For one, let us start with story. What the Serious Heck, I mean seriously, What the Heck! This game had a amazing storyline that is at first not obvious to gamer's eye and WOW! The ending! Personally, one of the better storylines that leaves you hanging at the end. On this, the game could not seem to fail at all...That is until we hit Gameplay... Gosh, that was annoying. You will strangle yourself much like that creepy tree event does at some points. Ugh, I thought this would be fun, not tear out your hair. While it is fun to explore the house, the things you are supposed to be doing is unobvious and you often get stuck. The puzzles were fun however and when you get to some of them they are interesting and a challange. It is the grab the hook you missed in the other room kind of thing that got me annoyed. This is a horror game so let us mention scares. Anna is not a jump scare kind of horror, although there is a few instances. (I HATE YOU TREE LADY!) Overall, the atmosphere, the spectacular audio, and the creepy events that leave you scared to move foward for a few seconds are what get to you. The backstory and some rooms also really add to this factor. Graphics were a problem for me for the the first hourish of gameplay. The graphics were not bad in any way what so ever. It was a certain glitch on my computer that made me almost end the total go through. I did solve this however, but had to play on a small window screen. 800x600 to be exact. Not too much of a problem although it caused some google searching and experimentation to fix the problem.The last thing I want to mention is the music and sound. Those both really took me in and freaked me out! Not to mention the game giving you ten songs of theirs to listen too. Wow, however composed the music did a excellent job. Not forgetting the ingame sounds that send chills down your spine. This area earned a perfect score for me in the game.Overall, I say play it. The game has its bugs and can be annoying however! The story is not to be missed and the sound/audio/atmosphere/ and so much more really make a excellent game.TotalStory-10/10Gameplay-5/10Scares-8/10Graphics-7/10Audio-10/10Overall 40/50Play the game, expect some frustration however... Just remember, the other stuff in the game make up for it!

content:

												I've always found this game to be oddly... Charming, in a way. It brought me to love a character whose face you never really see, whose voice is all you hear, and whose name resonates in your mind like a song stuck in your head with every step you take. Overall the game stuck with me because of the ambience and mood of the world as a whole. The story itself is somewhat unremarkable, but the way it's told is another case entirely, and very nicely lends itself to the style of the game. Overall I recommend it for a once or twice off enjoyable experience.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2014
												This game is a straight-up adventure game that should appeal to anyone that is a fan of those types of games.  I found it a fun diversion from my usual FPS and RPG games.  The developers put in a phrase that says, It Makes No Sense, when you are doing something wrong that kept me laughing as I tried multiple things to move the story forward.  The game is short, like scary short, like is $10 worth 3 hours of play, kind of short.  The story gets "BIZARRE" as you continue and I had some 70's flashbacks on many levels.  The blacklight room art caused quite a bit of amusement in my home!!  LOL!  I bought this game on sale for a couple of dollars down from  $10 and I don't feel like I was cheated.   Just understand that this game is very short and can be easily finished in 3 hours or less!  The story is actually interesting and I found the game to be fun to play.  If all that sounds good, then play on :)

content:
Posted: August 4, 2014
												When I first booted up this game my expectations sat somewhere between one of those dreadful mobile hidden object games and Amnesia the Incompetent Descent. Suffice to say I had no idea what this game was.Though a bit rough on the eyes, Anna is a surprisingly enjoyable puzzle adventure game. Though I never played them as a child, I imagine this game would be vaguely nostalgic to those who grew up addicted to the likes of Myst and the spin-offs that arose from it's success.In Anna you explore a world in the first person view, while solving puzzles in a classic, retro style point and click fashion. Luckily as far as I have seen, there is no absurd Sierra logic behind the item combinations.Driving the gameplay forward is an underlying narrative that's a bit of a mix between horror and psychosis with some supernatural sprinkled on top for good measure. I can't say that I have too strong of an understanding of the plot thus far, but I'm interested none the less.

Overall the game stuck with me because of the ambience and mood of the world as a whole. The story itself is somewhat unremarkable, but the way it's told is another case entirely, and very nicely lends itself to the style of the game. Overall I recommend it for a once or twice off enjoyable experience.

I ran it windowed, let it show me the un-skippable opening animation again. I clicked new game -- and the window went out of focus. I licked back in the window, clicked new game again, and again was outside the window.  It had somehow captured the off-set to my mouse and refused to re-acquire it.I'd like to play this game and give it a good review, but it just does not work.Owned it for a year, never gotten to play it.  Glad I bought it on sale.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												This game is way far from the kind I'm addicted to, so all pros and contras mentioned below are nothing more than how the thing are looking through the scope of my (casual player's) perception:The main con worth mentioning is being totally out of option to kick asses all the game through or get busy with any other equivalent kind of action. That's the worst part :). Another (lesser) issue I had(first couple of times i tryed to play it) was about the game play "rhythm", which lead me to some difficulties with balancing immersion and progress through the story. Too many dead ends and game-critical fatalities followed by annoying false endings you cannot skip(or save game reloadings).Pros are more prolific. The game's mood is a mix of gloomy, grim, mournfool and melancholic ones, and so is the look of locations you're doomed to spend most of your time in-game. Music, voice acting, the sense of things you discover along the story are all of the same colour. Yet there's a lot of impressive beauty put into it.The storyline seems very ambiguous, especially one in the extended version, giving much more information, mostly of the kind which makes things even more obscure than they were before you got "updated'.  As a result, it looks like one (relatively clear) story with random elements of two others attached to it to increase the volume of content. Not saying it's bad, this simulation of mysteries yet-to-reveal greatly contributed to my own interest towards what the game was trying to tell before i found out enough to figure things out(though i'm not sure this rate of clearness is really enough for it, even after checking what wikipedia says :)). Anyway, the whole thing is impressive and immersive enough to make me want to get that "you've completed this game 100%" achievement.After all, I've got myself loads of worlds to save, locations to clean sweep and a variety of hostile asses to kick in other games with much more obvious game stories.And than get back to this one and finish what's left of it to complete.Recommended, good game, 8 of 10 ---------------------------Вообще игра не из тех в которых я стандартно рублюсь, так что все за и против, которые я перечисляю ниже это не более чем то как она смотрится через прицел моего (как случайного игрока) восприятия.Главный косяк это конечно то, что в этой игре не надо(и нельзя) никого валить на всем ее протяжении, и нет какого либо другого эквивалента активной деятельности. Это главный недостаток :)).Другой, (менее важный) раздражавший в первую пару заходов в игру фактор, это некоторая сложность нахождения баланса между погружением в мир игры и успешным продвижением по сюжету. Многовато тупиков и фатальностей, приводящих или к периодическим просмотрам занудных неотключаемых ложных концовок или к перезагрузкам с сейвов.Плюсов побольше.Атмосфера в игре - смесь мрачного, зловещего, печального и меланхолического начал, как раз в тон окраске локаций, в которых проходит бОльшая часть игрового времени.Музыка, озвучка и сам смысл элементов сюжета, образно говоря, все того же цвета. Однако во все это вложено и немало мрачной красоты.История  кажется во многом непонятной, особенно в расширенной версии, где информации гораздо больше, но в основном она вся того рода, после которого начинаешь понимаешь чуть ли не меньше чем до того, как тебя "проинформировали".  Похожа она в результате на одну более менее понятнуюю историю, к которой приделано несколько случайных элементов от пары других историй ради увеличения общего объема. Не пытаюсь сказать что это плохо, эта симуляция тайн, которые предстоит раскрыть лично мне изрядно добавляла интереса к тому, что эта игра пытается рассказать до того, как я узнал достаточно, чтобы начать что то понимать в сюжете. Не уверен правда что имеющейся степени понятности для этого достаточно. Даже после ознакомления с тем что по этому поводу пишет википедия)).Но в целом игра впечатлила и заинтересовала достаточно для того, чтобы хотелось ее допроходить до ачивки "вы завершили эту игру на 100%".  У меня в конце концов хватает игр с гораздо более очевидными сюжетами, где можно спасти миры, зачистить локации и надрать всевозможные вражеские задницы.А потом вернуться к этой и допроходить до полной ясности.Короче в целом рекомендую, игра хорошая, 8 из 10

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 14, 2013
												Anna - Extended Edition review: Anna is a spooky as hell game, it's not much more than a point-and-click adventure game, yet it is so much more than a point-and-click adventure game. You play an 'amnesiac' who is drawn to an old abandoned sawmill, where some really disturbing events happened and you need to discover who you are and why this 'Anna' calls to you. The main gameplay mechanism is - pick up items and combine/use items on things in the environment to progress the story. I found that some of the puzzles were kind of absurd, like use a stick to smash through a concrete slab, but for the most part they are fairly consistent to the world. You will run into puzzles that you might think are completely absurd, mostly the ones dealing with occult rituals, but once you know the story and can decipher the metaphors everything begins to connect. This is what I found most entrancing about this game and it kept me thinking about the story even throughout the day.Now, I have not yet unlocked the 'True Ending' yet, so I still don't even know everything about the story. But I have received the 'Good Ending' and I am not going to spoil anything, but once you understand the ending, it really is a, "holy♥♥♥♥♥♥quot;, kind of moment. Despite still wanting to get the 'True Ending', I am hesitant, since this game gives me serious anxiety. It is not jump out of your seat scary, or will have you screaming in fear. But the whole mood of the game has this lingering malice that is always present, like a evil entity is constantly watching you. There are also hallucinations that sometimes occur which can have some disturbing imagery, or the god-awful sounds, specifically that women dying in the bedroom (you know what I'm talking about if you've played this game) that can really drive you mad.I laud the Italian dev team for the unique story, and the fact that the more you play - the more you discover; there are details in every corner and each one adds something to the story. The aesthetics are also well crafted and blend with the environment. It really feels like an old abandoned European log cabin in the woods (not the movie). And as a matter of fact Anna has a tone similar to a Grimm fairy tale. This is not going to be a game for everyone specifically the less patient or possibly the Amnesia fans. I can easily see some players getting bored with the game, to scared to play, or annoyed by having to look up a guide to solve some puzzles (I had to use a guide several times). But I still do highly recommend it, if you are looking for something new and spooky with a rewarding story, then Anna is for you.Recommend.

content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												After finishing through the "Truth" ending I felt so compelled to write a review on the game. To say the least, this gaming experience had its unforseen ups and downs. It balances out in the end, but overall it was a gaming experience I do not often have.For one, let us start with story. What the Serious Heck, I mean seriously, What the Heck! This game had a amazing storyline that is at first not obvious to gamer's eye and WOW! The ending! Personally, one of the better storylines that leaves you hanging at the end. On this, the game could not seem to fail at all...That is until we hit Gameplay... Gosh, that was annoying. You will strangle yourself much like that creepy tree event does at some points. Ugh, I thought this would be fun, not tear out your hair. While it is fun to explore the house, the things you are supposed to be doing is unobvious and you often get stuck. The puzzles were fun however and when you get to some of them they are interesting and a challange. It is the grab the hook you missed in the other room kind of thing that got me annoyed. This is a horror game so let us mention scares. Anna is not a jump scare kind of horror, although there is a few instances. (I HATE YOU TREE LADY!) Overall, the atmosphere, the spectacular audio, and the creepy events that leave you scared to move foward for a few seconds are what get to you. The backstory and some rooms also really add to this factor. Graphics were a problem for me for the the first hourish of gameplay. The graphics were not bad in any way what so ever. It was a certain glitch on my computer that made me almost end the total go through. I did solve this however, but had to play on a small window screen. 800x600 to be exact. Not too much of a problem although it caused some google searching and experimentation to fix the problem.The last thing I want to mention is the music and sound. Those both really took me in and freaked me out! Not to mention the game giving you ten songs of theirs to listen too. Wow, however composed the music did a excellent job. Not forgetting the ingame sounds that send chills down your spine. This area earned a perfect score for me in the game.Overall, I say play it. The game has its bugs and can be annoying however! The story is not to be missed and the sound/audio/atmosphere/ and so much more really make a excellent game.TotalStory-10/10Gameplay-5/10Scares-8/10Graphics-7/10Audio-10/10Overall 40/50Play the game, expect some frustration however... Just remember, the other stuff in the game make up for it!

												This game is a technical mess when I played it last...First off, this game is so awfully optimized that as soon as I stepped in the sawmill, my framerate dropped to about 15. Several things were off about the lighting as well, where as if I stared at a light for too long, it ended up growing and growing in brightness, until I finally turned away from it so it would go back to its normal brightness.Finally, when I actually DID get a decent framerate (which ended up being only outside of the sawmill), movement felt unnatural; when I ran over certain objects, I'd end up getting hopelessly stuck.All in all, if you're REALLY curious as to what this game is, either look it up on Youtube, or wait until this game's on a rediculously low sale.

content:
Posted: December 21, 2012
												I know it's been a long time since I wrote my previous review, but now I feel the review didn't describe the game enough.Anna is a game where you explore clues and where you try to find a mysterious woman named...well...Anna.Graphics:The graphics are downright gorgeous. This is something where you can close your eyes and feel that you are in the atmosphere. While they seem beautiful at first in the first scene of the game, it goes down towards the mystery and the creepy, scary side.Music:While this game only has a few tracks, the music is beautifully well done with acoustic guitar, violin, and piano. This is the kinda music you want to listen to while you're getting into the game or relaxing and touches your soul.Gameplay:There are two versions of the game: Original and Extended. The Original is more simple than the extended. It just focuses on items and getting through the game. The Extended, however, is more complicated, as there are more places to explore, more types of items to explore, and decisions and explorations that can affect the ending of the game. The upside of the Extended is that the story goes deeper.With the differences aside, there is some weirdness with some items of the game. You have to combine items you didn't expect that go together or used on something, or items that are well hidden. This can be a downside for simple players or people who don't wanna spend so much minutes on figuring stuff out.Story:The story goes into a sort of mystery and cultish feel with going back to some parts of the past. Yes, this game has some jumpscares, but in a perfect amount. I don't want to get into details, but the story is simply looking for a woman you can't get out of your head and you have an obsession. Not a crazy, sick obsession, but more of a desire just to be with the woman.In conclusion:Anna is one of those explorative, story gems that is a must have in your library and must be played. The graphics, music, and story melt perfectly into the pot that makes it a masterpiece. While the gameplay might be a bit annoying, the rest of the game will encourage you to delve further to solve the mystery.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 28, 2014
												Anna - Extended edition is a horror/adventure game without deaths and chasing monsters. Instead it pressures a player with a ghastly, dark athmosphere where paranormal things happen and twisted hallucinations appear. The story begins at a courtyard of a homely cottage surrounded with beautiful peaceful landscapes. At the first moments the game explains a bit about a male protogonist's background with few sentences, which reveal that man suffers amnesia and has somekind of overwhelming obsession on the cottage."This is the house which keeps appearing in my nightmares. ...How did I end up here anyway?"After the short perioid of relaxing puzzle solving strange supernatural things begin to happen: these events will not leave in dropping food cans nor mysterious voices, but instead take increasingly scaier features which I won't list here to avoid spoilers. I'll just say that this is about a very terrifying game where it is really hard to make yourself confortable.The gameplay in "Anna" is excelent and offers various interesting puzzles, whereas some of them honestly were a little dumb and far fetched. Luckily though player is provided with customizable hint system which can be turned on/off whenever player wants. As in many other adventure games during quest the inventory is filled with many items, which can be examined and attached together. As a new innovation player also gathers some thoughts and conclusions that can be blended together to see some details about the story.Anna - Extended edition surprised me as a game and especially as a horror game, which storyline eventually sorted out to be sad, but also inspiring. I hope that the develeopers carry on with the same genre.

												I really want to like this game. I love the atmosphere, I like the puzzles, I want to know the story.  But the game is not supported, it is technically broken, and it is unplayable.On my previous Mac it would run for about 5 minutes and then freeze. But I finally gave up.Before writing this review I installed it again, booted it up again. I have a new machine and thought "maybe they fixed it."  I ran it windowed, let it show me the un-skippable opening animation again. I clicked new game -- and the window went out of focus. I licked back in the window, clicked new game again, and again was outside the window.  It had somehow captured the off-set to my mouse and refused to re-acquire it.I'd like to play this game and give it a good review, but it just does not work.Owned it for a year, never gotten to play it.  Glad I bought it on sale.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
												This game is way far from the kind I'm addicted to, so all pros and contras mentioned below are nothing more than how the thing are looking through the scope of my (casual player's) perception:The main con worth mentioning is being totally out of option to kick asses all the game through or get busy with any other equivalent kind of action. That's the worst part :). Another (lesser) issue I had(first couple of times i tryed to play it) was about the game play "rhythm", which lead me to some difficulties with balancing immersion and progress through the story. Too many dead ends and game-critical fatalities followed by annoying false endings you cannot skip(or save game reloadings).Pros are more prolific. The game's mood is a mix of gloomy, grim, mournfool and melancholic ones, and so is the look of locations you're doomed to spend most of your time in-game. Music, voice acting, the sense of things you discover along the story are all of the same colour. Yet there's a lot of impressive beauty put into it.The storyline seems very ambiguous, especially one in the extended version, giving much more information, mostly of the kind which makes things even more obscure than they were before you got "updated'.  As a result, it looks like one (relatively clear) story with random elements of two others attached to it to increase the volume of content. Not saying it's bad, this simulation of mysteries yet-to-reveal greatly contributed to my own interest towards what the game was trying to tell before i found out enough to figure things out(though i'm not sure this rate of clearness is really enough for it, even after checking what wikipedia says :)). Anyway, the whole thing is impressive and immersive enough to make me want to get that "you've completed this game 100%" achievement.After all, I've got myself loads of worlds to save, locations to clean sweep and a variety of hostile asses to kick in other games with much more obvious game stories.And than get back to this one and finish what's left of it to complete.Recommended, good game, 8 of 10 ---------------------------Вообще игра не из тех в которых я стандартно рублюсь, так что все за и против, которые я перечисляю ниже это не более чем то как она смотрится через прицел моего (как случайного игрока) восприятия.Главный косяк это конечно то, что в этой игре не надо(и нельзя) никого валить на всем ее протяжении, и нет какого либо другого эквивалента активной деятельности. Это главный недостаток :)).Другой, (менее важный) раздражавший в первую пару заходов в игру фактор, это некоторая сложность нахождения баланса между погружением в мир игры и успешным продвижением по сюжету. Многовато тупиков и фатальностей, приводящих или к периодическим просмотрам занудных неотключаемых ложных концовок или к перезагрузкам с сейвов.Плюсов побольше.Атмосфера в игре - смесь мрачного, зловещего, печального и меланхолического начал, как раз в тон окраске локаций, в которых проходит бОльшая часть игрового времени.Музыка, озвучка и сам смысл элементов сюжета, образно говоря, все того же цвета. Однако во все это вложено и немало мрачной красоты.История  кажется во многом непонятной, особенно в расширенной версии, где информации гораздо больше, но в основном она вся того рода, после которого начинаешь понимаешь чуть ли не меньше чем до того, как тебя "проинформировали".  Похожа она в результате на одну более менее понятнуюю историю, к которой приделано несколько случайных элементов от пары других историй ради увеличения общего объема. Не пытаюсь сказать что это плохо, эта симуляция тайн, которые предстоит раскрыть лично мне изрядно добавляла интереса к тому, что эта игра пытается рассказать до того, как я узнал достаточно, чтобы начать что то понимать в сюжете. Не уверен правда что имеющейся степени понятности для этого достаточно. Даже после ознакомления с тем что по этому поводу пишет википедия)).Но в целом игра впечатлила и заинтересовала достаточно для того, чтобы хотелось ее допроходить до ачивки "вы завершили эту игру на 100%".  У меня в конце концов хватает игр с гораздо более очевидными сюжетами, где можно спасти миры, зачистить локации и надрать всевозможные вражеские задницы.А потом вернуться к этой и допроходить до полной ясности.Короче в целом рекомендую, игра хорошая, 8 из 10

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
												I tried out this game recently after a friend said I would love this game,and MAN was he right :).The plot is about an unnamed man(the character you play as),who has recurring nightmares about a sawmill and a woman named Anna. As you investigate the sawmill,finding various items and intuitions(basically little bits and pieces of your character's memories),you begin to find out the whole story of just what happened in the sawmill,who Anna is,and just what our character did to Anna,witnessing several horrifying events as you piece together the truth.The characters are pretty good,especially that wood mannequin that looks like a woman(I can't reveal who the mannequin is because of spoilers),which creeped me out/scared me several times in my 10 hour playthrough. xDThe music is really good,especially the music that plays during when you're outside the sawmill,and the credits themes.The atmosphere in this game is amazing,where one moment you have that music from outside the sawmill playing,making you feel all safe,and then the next there's some creepy music with that mannequin woman right in your face. The gameplay is pretty great,which involves solving dif puzzles to progress,and after Stage 2,a sanity meter is added,which lowers the longer you look at a"creepy event"(an example would be looking at the woman mannequin for too long).The puzzles are kinda challenging your first time through,and the difficulty of the puzzles really depends on if you know what you're doing,and have the items you need(which sometimes your first time through you can miss,believe me I missed about 4 items in Living Quarters,and had to go back there 4 times xD)Overall,this is a VERY good horror game that I recommend to everyone,even those that haven't played horror puzzle games like this.9.5/10 from me :)

number of helpful: 3 of 6 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 24, 2014
												Anna Extended Edition- Explore The Darker Side Of Human Psyche.Hey there! Thanks for reading my #2 Review, on Anna Extended Edition. I kind of liked Anna despite the fact that it received Mixed reviews, I honestly feel this game is a gem, and a must-grab during sales and of course, a must-play in your library. What is Anna? Anna is a first person immersive puzzle horror that revolves around an unnamed protagonist who finds himself in front of an abandoned house because he saw that house in his dreams. That's stupidity at it's finest, but I would personally go there if it's a woman calling, and same stuff happened here, he heard Anna, calling him. This protagonist enters the house and roams around, doing stuff, and discovers what really happened, and to be honest, the ending wasn't what I expected, but it was sad. It was not predictable.Descriptive Analysis! Anna Extended Edition is developed by Dreampainters. The developers are Italian-based. The company is totally indie, by totally I mean, TOTALLY, T-O-T-A-L-L-Y. This game fits in the definition of Indie. So, I was browsing their site, here you go, http://dreampainterssoft.com and saw, "To design and develop the best narrative games with the highest possible quality.”And they did, Anna is a hidden gem. The company seems to be composed of fairly young people with minimal experience, and Anna being their first game, and to be honest, they did exceptionally good for their first game. The game is minimalistic. No HUD, Good sound effects, a nice BGM and good visuals. A good combination, something like I want from games. This game is extremely narrative and hence you should not buy it if you don't like slow narration. As you know, I'm a soundtrack-♥♥♥♥♥ and hence I would just play this game to hear the beautiful soundtrack. So, let's start now.Gameplay-The game is a typical FPS. This is the first game I've played in narrative category, and the second one being Dear Esther(I didn't like Dear Esther). I guess I haven't played enough games to set standard for grading, but still, it's good. Unlike Dear Esther, you solve actual puzzles. You click stuff, you examine stuff, like a Point 'n' Click with FPS. There is an inventory system, and a journal system where the protagonist's darker side is hidden. They're really long, really, but to understand the storyline, I recommend you do that, and complete the game at your own pace. Typical WASD controls. Mechanics and Features-The game is psychological horror so don't expect jump scares. The game gets predictable sometimes but you would still pee in your pants, that's because it's happening exactly the way you don't want. The game won't throw stuff at you directly, but in a random pattern, same places, same stuff, but random moments, when you won't be expecting them. I literally put down my headphones because one such encounter scared me, not 'to death' but still very much.The game has good collision data, and physics, although, physics don't matter much, but still you would notice some bugged out places in the game. Like a floating chair(NOT PART OF THE GAMEPLAY, ACTUAL BUG BUT STILL SCARY).Another feature I liked is the 'Truth' feature. You have to examine stuff to remind the protagonist what really happened. This makes you think what is worth examining, although you could examine everything. There's another minute feature that still adds some fun, exiting the house. Instead of an average horror movie where the door gets locked, you actually have a choice to exit the house, but the game would end and give you an ending depending upon which moment you ran out of the house. There are achievements for rational thinking like this too!The Plot-The plot is boring at first, until you enter the house. Nice BGM with bright colours, my ideal holiday spot, but once you enter, the colours fade, you enter darkness, you'll poop your pants. The storyline is intriguing, but not at a level you'd want it to be. It's narrative, slow and easy to understand. The storyline has a few plot twists, the ending itself is one. There are multiple choices, depending upon how you play the game, which alters the final ending. But let me tell you, you won't feel happy. None of the endings is like how you would expect. I kinda expected Anna Ressure..*oops* No Spoilers.Difficulty Level-A bit difficult since you don't know what to do unless and until you read the journal, carefully hear the narrations and use common sense.OVERALL!Graphics-Good. Not bad. It's an indie, I don't care about graphics but it deserves an 8/10.Gameplay+Mechanics-Narrative, Slow, Multiple choices, random encounters. Deserves 7/10Price-I don't have a problem buying it at 10$ but you should wait for sales.Soundtrack-Pls, the one aspect I loved the most <3. Buy the soundtrack. Worth the money?Yes, kind of. IF you're a Dear Esther fan or into atmospheric, narrative, horror, psychological, you should get this. Assuming you're new to narrative ones, I'd like you to give this one a try. I don't think you would regret it. Well, if you liked my review, join this group:-http://steamcommunity.com/groups/JustAnotherIndieGamer

content:
Posted: September 10, 2016
												Great atmosphere that is dark and creepy, but the game couldn't figure out if it wants to be an adventure game or a horror game.The puzzles are fairly obtuse and often have you trying to translate books written by a lawyer or pixel hunting for something you missed.Health doesn't have a place in a game like this, and any time limit doesn't either.  You don't have any explanation for what is damaging you and seemingly get randomly punished....for exploring.So basically...don't explore or look around and you're fine...sort of.  But then what the hell is the point of the game being a mystery if you can't explore without being punished?The health system is just sheer incompetence and a severe misunderstanding of the genre.That aside, the story feels weak and the first time you get expelled from the place you are left wondering wtf?  I put on a mask, then was literally not allowed to leave the room where I'd be hit by something that wrecks my health....because "I can't leave now, something it about to happen" after 5 minutes of waiting.

content:
Posted: April 20, 2013
												Anna is a great indie horror adventure. The game has a good storytelling and a nicely designed environment, enhanced by the excellent sound. You can play the original version (which is really short) or the extended edition.The extended edition features more environments, more hours of gameplay, more puzzles, enhanced graphics and an improved interface.In Anna you are  trying to discover why this place is so special and who the woman with the name Anna is. For the progress you are searching your surroundings for items that you can use to progress and to solve puzzles.The puzzles are interesting, some clearly more challenging than others, but mostly solvable.Fans of the horror genre should give Anna a try. Sound 9/10Graphics 8/10Gameplay 7/10Atmosphere 9/10If you liked my review, please feel free to follow me and/or my curator group:http://steamcommunity.com/id/Ov3RT4K3R/myworkshopfiles/?section=guideshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/orcollective#curationAlso feel free to check out my YouTube Channel: https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC83DYCmrWfl9ttrhX54jmWA

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
												I was trying hard to like this game, or at least trying to actually play it to see what it is. But that task is just impossible, because this game is an horrible technical mess!First you have to spent an hour just to familiarize yourself with the clunky controls and the horrible mouse sensibility. After that you think your problems are gone, but they're not... you found a lot of things you can do with your collected objects, but very soon you realize they don't make any sense, so you start to search and try every bizarre combination to try to solve simple puzzles and this take long, much more long than your patience.The worst is... every new room i entered i got struggle with a buggy blinking environment lights that makes me literally close my eyes to not being blind. Sometimes it stop in a few seconds, sometimes don't, and i found me running or shaking the mouse trying to stop the madness. Sometimes i had to go to options and click every button, then it stops.It is really a shame that game being published this way, because i really like the mystery mood, but it's really impossible to play. In the Steam forums you see any decent answer either by Dreampainters or Kalypso Media. You just don't get any support, unless a false statement that is a Unity problem. You buy a broken game and it's your own problem, they'll not fix it.Also, you have to make a Kalypso account and login in a launcher every time you start the game, even with no online resources. This publisher is one of the worst i ever seen, they don't have any respect or care with customers. I'll skip any title  under their label forever.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2013
												I am torn with this game. I suppose I just couldn't get into it, but I will give this game credit where it is due : it is very creative and this ''Extented Edition'' is a vast upgrade over the original. It is also gorgeous and is a real work of art, so I REALLY recommend this game for anyone (like me) that believes games can be art. It is a very mature game, not for the faint of heart, and not for the easily bored.It was also VERY freaky, and it just got freakier and freakier, to the point that I started to feel just as insane as the character I was playing. Yeah, you're not supposed to look directly at the freaky♥♥♥♥♥♥that pops up to scare you. You have a kind of insanity meter, and its game over if it runs out. You then get the bad ending, which was my ending. Couldn't finish the game you see, but that wasn't really the reason.The reason I don't REALLY want to recommend this game, but I will anyway due to the aforementioned points, is the puzzles. They make little to no sense. The whole game is heavily cryptic, to the point of insanity... and I guess its kinda the point, but I couldn't even get passed the first area without a walkthrough, and I don't think that's a point in its favor. Yes, you'll sometimes find a few clues in the form of books as to what to do next, but they are vague at best, or seem to have no connection with anything at worst. I just went in circles, revisiting room after room after room (once I finally unlocked them), not understanding what to do until I finally saw too many hallucinations and it was over. I guess there's two words to describe this : beautiful... but weird. VERY WEIRD.So, I am tempted to continue this game, but it is as a big freaky impassable wall of nonsensical puzzles, which only the metaphorical industrial drill of a walkthrough can penetrate, which kinda destroys the immersion it tries to create. And if you do get through, blood will spill out and you'll go insane, then its game over. That pretty much sums up my experience.THUMBS UP FOR ARTSYNESS THOUGH. I will not replay this though. Give it a try... if you dare...

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 9, 2014
												This game has a few issues. It doesn't start off on a good footing by making you sign up for some account that serves only to advertise another game before you start. The game itself is beautiful with a very dark, sinister atmosphere. The inventory system is not very good and the way of moving objects is useless. The puzzles are nigh on incompressible. The built in help system does nothing except either tell you to do things that you have already done or tell you things there are no help at all. I am not the best puzzle gamer, I will generally reach for a walkthrough more often than necessary but here quite early on I just gave up any attempt at solving the puzzles and followed a walkthrough in its entirety. There is a health meter but the game is really not that clear on what injures you so losing health just feels arbitrary. Through the game you collect intuitions and offers no explanation as to what they are but you need to work this out to progress to the final endings. All these things do not mean I did not enjoy this game, the mystery and the story kept me wanting to carry on. The multiple endings add a bit of replayability This game also comes with the original Anna so you can play that and realise that the terrible inventory, controls and incomprehensible puzzles are a significant improvement on the original. Completing certain endings on the original is dependent upon random events you have no control over happening which is annoying. So overall I am giving this a thumbs up, it is flawed but pull up a walkthrough and enjoy the atmosphere and story.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 8, 2014
												Weird, Glitchy, and Confusing.A glitch I ran into was that I was able to force a door open via physics manipulation (just grabbing the locked door and spazzing out with the mouse basically on numberous points) that was magically sealed and that I was not supposed to be able to open until a puzzle was finished. This big of a glitch makes me thing there are likely more software related issues, as on the steam forums many complain about unstable performance. But my experience was that game ran fine at most times with any lack of performance possibly my hardware setup.Graphically the game looks good. But its a very very small scope type of game, but it looks nice and isn't hard to run.Its most like one of those DOS text adventure or later on when point and click type of adventure games came on. But unfortunately like some of them this game can be very confusing.  Eventually puzzles can amount to just randomly clicking on stuff until you get the right combo which is just a waste of time. At points some elements were really interesting in the puzzles, but more often than not it just made no sense or was illogical and confusing.  The books do help some but they only give you an inkling and the tips system if your stuck but have an idea of what you have to do is next to useless.The seemingly random events such as stuff popping up or happening was interesting. And for the most part good. Look at something only to look away and back and its moved or gone. Gives a very creepy feeling that you are not safe and the world around you is alive. Which alot of games falter at and end up with a static feeling enviroment. As you progress the game world changes around you.The only problem is that puzzles are just anti-intuitive at times and just to much and thats pretty much all the gameplay. Just walking around and interacting with things that are apart of puzzles. The story is spooky ghost sprittual stuff from what I can tell. But I didn't really get it.If you want a confusing puzzle game where you pretty much have to google atleast some part of the puzzles or waste hours trying to figure them out then I suppose this maybe for you. Sure the game could possibly draw you in, but once your there your stuck at a puzzle while you want to adventure in a world unlike one your used to.Something I think this game could have been really great with is some top notch narration for books, and other parts where there is onscreen text your intended to read. Also making the text in as small and biteable chunks as possible instead of a giant wall of text paragraph that the in game books are. This would make them less of a chore to read and with the narration it would be possibly pleasurable to listen to if was anything like Bastions narration.

content:
Posted: June 23, 2014
												This game is a excellent example of the survival horror genre. It is reminiscent of the Nintendo Gamecube cult classic Eternal Darkness in that it is puzzle based and very much focused on horror that is in the main player characters mind rather than stalking zombies, or deadly plagues, or the apocalypse. The atmosphere is spooky and intimidating and the player has a wide variety of options in game that effect what achievements they get as well as the final outcome of the game. The only problem is that the controls are a bit touchy and there is no controller support for this game. Overall this game gets 4.5 out of 5 for horror ambiance.

I really congratulate the team.This game made me wonder what if the video game industry funds this type of games that I think immortal pieces of art. I hope that virtual reality tech to clear the way for these kind of games.

number of helpful: 2 of 5 people (40%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 3, 2014
												Anna is a first-person adventure/horror game. What I liked most is the suspenseful atmosphere and the story. Game's setting changes drastically over a few stages: first you find yourself outside a wooden sawmill, observing as the sun glistens from a calmly running stream. You feel intrigued to get inside the house and learn of it's secrets. Once you're inside - it gets pretty spooky. You solve puzzles and trigger scripted and random events to progress in the story. The puzzles are satisfying but usualy don't make much sense and are not really intuitive. I had to look up a few playthroughs to solve some puzzles - couldn't come up with solutions myself. Once you reach a certain point in the story, the setting becomes really grim. With an unholy presence in the sawmill and ambient sounds that chill down your spine - the experience is quite satisfying even for a horror junkie. The game has multiple endings which adds some replay value. All in all, Anna is a decent game with some flaws regarding puzzles, but if you're up for the challenge and have plenty of spare time to come up somewhat ridiculous solutions to solve puzzles - get this game. 7/10

content:
Posted: August 13, 2014
												Hey everyone and this is my review about the game!This game is a Psychological horror with Puzzle exploration. Interface/Menu/SettingsThere are multiple Languages.There is a mouse Sensitivity (I do recommend to keep this at low, otherwise you could get a punishment).There is a Resolution Size and Quality settings.You can play this game in windows mode or Fullscreen.Main menu music is decently okay.You can turn the subtitles on or off.You are able to turn off or on the help system.You can change the controls.About the game.There is Dark atmosphere.Some "Scary" Events.Deep interesting good Storyline.There are Subtitles.Speeches are voiced over including with subtitles.Some Puzzles COULD be difficult.There is a "help" System for incase you get stuck. However, you are able to turn this off.The game has Multiple Endings.Sound is okay.You can use the mousewheel to scroll through items. But opening inventory is faster.Other things.YOU NEED A KEY IN ORDER TO PLAY THIS GAME - HOWEVER YOU GET THIS ONE AUTOMATICALLY ONCE YOU HAVE INSTALLED THIS. This requires a Kalypso Account.i have complete the game and it is very good. You might want to get this with a discount however.Just a Hint, do not turn the sensitivity of ur mouse high. Keep it at low, because you will get punished for it if you have it on high.Playing in window mode is not always super in this game. Because if you are scrolling around, there is a chance that you could click outside the border and click your desktop instead.Playing on lower resolution graphics, might be easier to find items.There are "Time based event" (SECRET) achievements.Sometimes you get stuck at something and that is really annoying. No, you can't jump!Game is short.Let's Try Video:

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2013
												Anna - Extended Edition might not be the greatest game that has ever been made, but it delivers a certain enchanting experience, which left me wanting to know everything about the story. The plot starts out confusing, but it unfolds as the player starts putting effort into the game, making it a great experience to puzzle together different elements of the story. The game rewards players who collect and read all the notes and books (and who experience all disturbing events) with a small cutscene to explain the deeper meaning behind one of the main characters, something a completionist like me highly appreciates! Overall Anna is a enjoyable game for those who like the experience a deep and thoughtprovoking story. Although the gameplay might be a bit boring and offsetting to some, it is worth the price that is being asked for it!

												Anna is a first person horror/puzzle story that journey's through a dark past. The visuals are beautiful, and the attention to detail is great. The game has good replayability because there are multiple endings and there's a very good chance you are going to miss things the first time through. The game really requires you to spend a lot of time playing around with objects and your surroundings, so unless you don't like to immerse yourself in a world, I highly recommend Anna.

												tldnr; if you like these types of games, you will like Anna. It's solid, especially if you can pick it up on sale. If you don't like these types of games, then of course you'll be disappointed. 8/10The story was original and interesting. Most of the bugs that are described in the negative reviews were part of the original game and have been fixed in the Extended Edition. Music and atmosphere are great. It starts out really creepy, and by the time the creepiness wears off, the game is about 75% over and the story has progressed to the point where it's not intended to try to scare you anymore. I thought the game really transitioned well between these two points.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: February 18, 2015
												I do recommend it, but I couldn’t have done it without the help of some walkthroughs. The puzzles are often not based on common sense, but on some sinister dark knowledge of witchcraft it seems. So I guess I used about 50% doing walkthroughs. It is dark and deep  and I really like the music and sound effects, they really add to a good experience. So if you don’t use walkthroughs I wish you good luck, but if you’re not afraid to get a little online help every once in a while, it’s ok. The story is good, and once you’re inside you really get sucked into it! I’ve done my first playthrough now and had one of 8 endings. Not the final ending though, which I’ve seen on youtube and is really worth trying again in the not too distant future. The thing I really missed was the experience you have in Amnesia, Among the Sleep or Outlast, where you occasionally have to run for your life. I have to add, there isn’t really anywhere to run or hide :p but despite this, the music, fx, story and puzzles make it creepy as hell. Whenever I play games like this, with bad or average games, I sometimes start to wonder when it’s going to end. With Anna, I was sad it had already ended :p Totally worth it!

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												This is game is really cool because it takes a while to get into, but once you're in you're ♥♥♥♥ing in it. If you played Sanity's Requiem on Gamecube all those years back, you'll be familiar with the idea of your character's sanity being important to maintain or else you lose the game. The same goes with Anna, for as you explore the story and the sawmill you also bear witness to supernatural events (most of which are not alarming) which damage your sanity. I think this game is brilliant because the setting changes dramatically over time as you progress and make little decisions. The darker your choices, the weirder things get and the more supernatural events you'll see. This is the kind of game where so much care and thought has been put into backstory and trivia that you can't help but lose yourself in it, and that makes it really enjoyable. Brilliant and well worth getting! *****

content:
Posted: May 9, 2014
												Pros:- Good Atmosphere - Very Silent Hill inspired story- Great soundtrack- Beautiful graphics for an indie game- Many endingsCons:- Confusing plot- Just puzzles and no action/monster pursuits at all-  These puzzles may be hard for many users who will not follow any guide ( i had no problem with this but it's what i heard by friends )- Many puzzles don't make much sense, you will have to guess rather than think- English translation isn't THAT good ( it's a bit spanglish even if the game is italian)- Very indie voice acting- Just one location to explore, and it has few rooms.- Terrible open/close doors controls- Needs an ingame tutorial for the insanity bar and logic buttons- Too many games like this style nowdays ( Slenderman, Amnesia,etc) and it can't be really compared to them.I have got this game for less than 2 euros, so that's why i am recommeding it, but i won't do it anymore when price will go back to 6 euros.

content:
Posted: May 16, 2014
												This point and click adventure is mysterious and frightening... especially if you hate mannequins. What first brought my attention to this game was the large amount of negativity people pointed towards this game for being 'a walking simulator' or 'having no gameplay and thus it isnt a game'. Those statements are completely false. Anna has alot of exploring, item collecting, puzzle solving, reading books and notes left in the game in order to complete and progress further into this game. The story and atmosphere are both unsettlingly great and interesting. This game is worth your time if you are into horror games or point and click adventurers.

content:
Posted: June 4, 2014
												This is a ♥♥♥♥ing beautiful game that's hurt by awkward controls.  Before I say I love the game, it should be acknowleged that the logic behind the puzzles is nearly nonexistent and follows dreamlike rules where the impression of connected events is enough to trigger the next thing.  Also as it's been noted, this isn't the most directly horrifying game.  Not in the raw tension Amnesia sense, or blood and guts sense.  However, it is one of the best examples of an unnerving and disturbing atmosphere, aided by the nonsensical dream-puzzle logic. Honestly, for $10 it is worth a playthrough.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2015
												Anna - Extended Edition is a unique and extremely creepy adventure game.  In fact, I thought that the audio and visuals were even more disturbing that the arguable more famous Amnesia.  The story is interesting and unfolds gradually as the player interacts with different puzzles and objects in an abandonded house, piecing together the mystery of what happened there.  There is no dialogue interactions in the game but the storytelling is well done without them.  The steam overlay, widescreen resolutions and steam achievements are supported but unfortunately the controller is not.  Anna's strength is also it's weakness, it is maddeningly difficult to figure out how to solve the puzzles.  In fact, this is a game that is nearly impossible to complete without the assistance of a walkthrough video.  However, the several possible endings based on the choices you make bring some replayability to the game that is often missing from adventure titles.  In all, Anna is a succesful but flawed entry into the genre and should be considered by anyone who enjoys a difficult adventure game.

number of helpful: 1 of 4 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 27, 2013
												Good psychological horror / puzzle adventure game - I don't want to give away any spoilers, but I will say that I had more frights in this game than even Amnesia TDD (well, maybe - Amnesia is damn good, you should definitely play it).Remember - headphones should be up loud and the lgihts should be off - if you're not psyched out to get scared you're doing it wrong.It's not a terribly long game - Steam reckons it only took me four hours to unlock the Truth ending, and some of that was walking around trying to find some object I had missed because it was right next to (and looked like part of) another much more interesting object (ye olde classic puzzle adventure game problem). On a positive note the game doesn't wait for you to make progress to decide to give you a scare, which nicely avoids the boredom problem that many adventure games have in that situation.It's actually probably for the best that it wasn't any longer - like many psychological horror games the scares have less and less impact as you get more used to them. By the end of the game I wasn't jumping whenever XXXXXXXX happened any more, which makes me think the length was about right (although that was in my second sitting - I'd recommend playing through the whole thing in one sitting if you can).Also, there are intuitions at the top of the inventory screen. I only mention this because I didn't notice until I was almost finished the whole game and it seems like they might have an influence on the ending.One annoyance I had with the game was that some of the cutscenes are unskippable - including the expelled ending sequence which happens when you lose too much sanity. Unfortunaly at one point I had saved a game with almost no sanity left and I had to keep sitting through that ending and reloading over and over until I was able to make some progress before the game threw another random event at me.One final warning - this game includes some 3rd party DRM. While it's far from the worst DRM scheme around it's still unwelcome - you will need to create an account with Kalypso before you can play.I also had some technical issues with my controls (the camera spun by itself every 5 seconds), though it mysteriousely resolved itself after a few attempts to launch the game.

content:
Posted: February 9, 2015
												Anna - Extended Edition does psychological horror better than any title I have ever played.  The sound, music, narration, story, design - all these things are absolutely remarkable, and Anna should be played by anyone who wants to see how a game like this should be done.Quite unfortunately, the entire game is left in ruins due to an insulting puzzle-solving mechanic.  If the other features build the perfect arc, all that's necessary is a keystone that'll just keep those things in place.  It doesn't exist, and worse, this was reportedly done on purpose.  You repeatedly pick up items that you'll never use.  Puzzles make no sense and worse, there's no effort for them to do so.  I tried my damndest to get through the game without a guide, but it's impossible.  Unless you plan to hammer away at this title for a solid month for hours on end each day, you will never figure out each puzzle.  Worse yet, there are multiple endings depending on how you play the game - and nothing is explained to you at any point.  There are useful guides online, but I'd imagine even THEY needed help before writing it, or they went into the game's code to make sense of it all.The only way I can recommend Anna is with a guide.  There are some on Steam and you can find some on YouTube.  They are non-negotiable.  If you want to enjoy Anna, you have to abandon your sense of integrity when it comes to solving puzzles on your own and use a guide.  If you can accept this, Anna will give you a new understanding of how games should be made with regards to every other feature.Specifically the horror.  This game, numerous times, sent chills down my entire body.  They started at my neck and spread throughout my body and to my arms and legs.  Yet, not once though was I afraid to continue.  I never thought I shouldn't do something because something's lurking around the corner.  This game does horror better than any other title.  It exists on a level above all others.  There are no jump-scares or smash cuts to scary images.  While I might react quickly to a zombie or monster in another game, in this there are no monsters.  The every-changing environment is enough to scare you.  One feature in particular is a visage of a woman made of wood that changes position and follows you.  It never attacks you, it's simply there.  Yet each time it appears in a place I don't expect, even if I was just looking there, it managed to get me almost every time.For this reason alone, I recommend Anna.  Everything in the game is fantastic.  The one thing that is completely absent, and insultingly so by design, is sensible puzzle solving.  If you can stomach the fact that you'll need a guide from the onset, this title is thoroughly enjoyable.

												story-you're playing as some unnamed guy,who keeps having dreams about some woman named Anna and the house in the mountains.so he goes here and enters the house where supernatural stuff starts to happeningthe games story is good-maybe not the most original and it would be great if i knew,who the heck am i playing as,but its mysterious enough to keep you interestedone of the biggest pros of this game are music and visuals-visuals,(for an indie game) are beautifull and has their own styleand music is the best thing about this game-melancholic mix of folk and subtle orchestral music matches the game perfectly and is just so gorgeous.but unfortunately game has its issue,one of them being puzzles-most of the times,you wont know what to do,because game doesnt tell you and some of the puzzles doesnt even make sense.so if you want to beat the game you have to have a walkthrough or you'll have to struggle with trial and error approach.and the puzzles are 99% of the game! also the game is a horror-and what a horror needs? jumpscares,of course! i'll give them their attemp to make jumpscares visually interesting and other times it works and other times dont.when it works-its visually interesting and kinda creepy,...but when it doesnt work-it feels forced and ends up ruining an atmospherepros:-wonderfull music-beatifull visuals(for an indie game)-good storycons:-puzzles-half of the scares in this gameverdict-Anna could be pretty good,it has great music,beautifull graphics and good story,but its all ruined by puzzles,which are 99% of the game.if you want to purchase game wait till the price drops and be ready to have some kind of a walkthrough5.5/10

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 29, 2013
												Despite the some of the special effects feeling a tad dated, I can honestly and with a straight face say that I have never reacted to a game like I reacted to this one. I can understand that many may not feel the same way upon playing, but my friend Skye can attest to the fact that I was yelling in shock and anxiety repeatedly while make my way through the game. The sound design is phenomenal in that often when you hear a sound there's nothing there...but sometimes there is...and it's that 1-in-10 moment that makes you jump out of your seat. The same principle is applied to the 'inhabitants' of the sawmill. These elements combine to create a living, unpredictable, and malevolent environment that continually surprises and engages you. My only criticisms extend to the occasionally insane difficulty and abstract nature of some of the puzzles, and the lack of explanation of the so-called 'intuitions', which, given how pivotal they are in regards to your experience, lack any in-game explanation as to their importance or function. The Extended Edition has many improvements over the original (longer game length, more puzzles, increased graphical quality) and, in my opinion, completely redeems the experience. 8.5/10.

number of helpful: 0 of 3 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
												Personally, I found the story pretty immersive. Wasn't so fond of some of the long texts since they felt like a break in the actual gameplay, but they were generally interesting to read. I didn't get very far, however, because some of the puzzles were rather obscure; it was very easy to miss one little thing and be stuck for a loooong time. Since there are barely any tutorials for the Extended Edition, it made it that much harder to figure out what to do when I got stuck (which happened fairly frequently). Granted, though, I'm not that great at puzzles. So although I'd recommend it, it's certainly not for everyone, especially those with little time to play.

												The plot is a little uncertain to me. Like, it's a dude searching for some chick, and I think the house meant something to them, or maybe she's dead? Dunno. After that it's kind of like, "oh hey, witchcraft! Or is it insanity? Or... BOTH?!" And then I'm unsure what the events that transpire are actually supposed to imply. Maybe it's more clear in the extended edition.Despite not having any real idea of what the hell was going on half the time, or why I was doing what I was doing, or what I was doing was supposed to mean, it was pretty cool. I don't know if it's a "puzzle game" so much as an "exploring and following instructions" game but it was still rather compeling and exquisitly stimulating. The scares are subtle, and few did more than make my heart flutter, but the ones that got me made me scream like a 12 year old Justin Bieber fan (or possibly, Justin Bieber).

												Fun scary game.  However, the events are just buggy and annoying to get too.  It seems as if certain scary events will only occur within a certain time frame of the game.  So this makes it a big pain trying to figure out when you can get an event, and when you can't. Didn't matter if you sped through everything to get to that point in less then 5 minutes, red shift event will happen and completely prevent you from getting that ending.  Annoying.Otherwise, a fun and scary adventure game.
