number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 3, 2013
												Anna isn't just any horror game. It's a first-person point-and-click puzzle horror game. I didn't think I'd actually experience fear, but it happened. Oh did it happen. The game doesn't rely on cheap "jump scares" (even though there were some), rather using its dynamic atmosphere to keep you feeling at constant unease. While it could have simply thrown you into the sinister sawmill from the beginning of the game, Anna let's you start outside in a gorgeous peaceful environment. This stark contrast really adds to your distress once you're inside the sawmill. From there, things quickly get darker and stranger.As for the minor negative aspects of the game; scrolling in the inventory box was annoying (had to click on up/down arrows, couldn't use the scroll wheel), there weren't any dedicated examine/use/pick up keys, nor mouse buttons (had to use a context menu), and of course, you had your typical absurd point-and-click puzzles that would either cause you to brute force the solution or look it up in a guide. Although to its credit the game does have an in-built hint system. I can also see that some people would find the slow walking speed tedious (I didn't). Some may argue that the overall game should not cause any fear since you quickly learn, by design, you can't die/lose and have an affect with any encounter; all you can do is simply look or (in vain) try to interact with an encounter. However, Anna does make it work and I'm not sure why. Perhaps it's the fact that you're ill-equipped and very limited in your interactions/movement, coupled with its powerful atmosphere? Overall, it's a decent game. Mechanically and aesthetically it achieves what it needed. The game should run you for ~4 hours depending on how fast you go through the puzzles.Thanks to kewpahtrewpah for kindly gifting me this game.

content:
Posted: July 8, 2014
												    !Minor spoiler!Anna is a mentally horrifying, horror adventure game that scared me ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥… I’m a wuss when it comes  to horror games so don’t take my word for it when I say this game is excellent…You get a bunch of these types of games like Amnesia and Outlast, but games like those use a scary monster with a big mouth and twitchy or slow and sluggish movement to scare the living daylights out of you when it BURSTS through a wall or suddenly appears behind you..Anna does what it does, very differently… It slowly builds tension and ever so slightly increases the eeriness of the environment and scares you using things like chairs and bursting steam pipes…If you had to personify games like Outlast and Anna: Outlast would be a creepy old man with a knife staggeringly approaching you in a dark alley and no matter where you turn, that old man is there, staggeringly approaching. While Anna on the other hand is a woman, standing with her back towards you slowly turning around until you see half her face expecting the rest to be horribly maimed, but instead it’s a perfectly normal woman with a loving look in her eyes. Then you suddenly realize that the thing you should be running from is the big ♥♥♥♥ing wooden “mom-doll” slowly emerging from behind the woman, reaching for you with her branch arms…I recommend this game for anyone into adventure and horror...

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 18, 2014
												Anna is a first person adventure game involving the supernatural and psychological horrors held within an old mountain sawmill/home that has fallen into disrepair.  You play as an, apparently un-named, history professor who has been mysteriously drawn the sawmill by a strong feeling of deja vu when he finds pictures of the place in his closet, despite having no memory of the place.When I watched the trailer on Steam I noticed that most of the objects in the game aren't even animated, and almost passed by this game because of it.  While it is true that there is almost no animation outside of physics objects, the mood and setup was all that's needed to emerse me into the game.  Also, because many of the objects are stationary, it led me to question whether the house is in fact haunted or if the man I was playing as was going insane.  It's obvious that this was an intentional choice as the game uses clever placement to ensure that you're not looking when certain objects move or materialize, which to be honest did make me jump a few times.The story of what happened at the sawmill and the ways in which I was required to reveal it are also better than I expected.  The things I was required to do to find out the truth made me question the sanity of the man I played as, and the truth itself is something that would probably cause the average person to go insane.  None of that "Timmy fell down a well and died and now he's a ghost that feels betrayed" crap.What little music is in the game is very good and, along with the sounds, enhances the experience of the game.My only negative criticism is that some of the puzzles require ridiculous logic to try to solve on your own and there are usually clues for each one they are either hard to find or not nearly enough to get you close to a solution.Recommended for anyone who likes adventure puzzles, solve it yourself stories, and psychological horror.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 29, 2014
												It's a first- person adventure game that takes place in a tiny sawmill.  Don't let the small size turn you away, though.  It can take a long time to solve all the puzzles that this game has to offer.  The puzzles range from practical challenges to Pagan rituals, and you'll have to carefully search the saw mill to find every item you'll need.  Supernatural events occur frequently, and they can lower your sanity, much like in Amnesia.    I should note that this is NOT point and click.  You move around freely like in most of the first person games we're used to.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 13, 2014
												So, I know this game got some pretty bad reviews by big critics. I'm going to have to stop you there.At first glance, this game appears to be an incredibly confusing and non-intuitive system. Sure, you've got the basic menu, click and point and click item use mechanic, you can walk and look just like normal. Crouching, but no jumping. And then you look around and realize you have no idea what you're supposed to do. Or that you do, but you can't. Perform the ritual? Ok, sure... how do I do that? What am I missing?Well, yes, yor objectives can be pretty obscure. More importantly, it can be easy to miss crucial items you might need, depending upon the path you choose. But, if you're careful, check everything twice, and read everything at least once (journals, books, letters, etc), the answers are all there. Experiment with things, and eventually, with the knowledge you gain from the protagonist's intuitions and documents scattered about, you will find the way.Keep in mind that in the original game there were only three endings, with one "true" ending. The extended edition has eight, giving moer variance than "leave now, leave then, or win the game." You can reach the end in the extended edition and STILL BE WRONG. It means you missed something along the way. But maybe you like that ending better. While there is a eries of events that must be performed to progress at all, the steps you take in between can matter greatly. Will you scour the depths of hell to find Anna? Or will you leave with your sanity and your life? Or perhaps you will follow in the footsteps of the Sabot Maker? I don't know, but if you don't choose carefully, you'll find your carelessness chooses for you.3.5/5, for obscurity but ingenuity.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2016
												I'm still in the early stages of Anna, but I wanted to review it so far.The game is interesting. I don't have a problem with the controls except the mouse sensitivity is kind of weird, but it's not a big deal. The graphics aren't bad, and the settings and sounds are creepy, which is good. I still don't quite understand the story quite yet though, like what all the voices are talking about in game, etc.The main problem I'm having with this game is the whole problem solving/puzzles thing. I didn't think it would be as difficult as it is. There should be better hints or something. I often have to use a play-through guide to figure out what to do next. It's rather confusing, and it feels like it takes me forever to figure some things out. So, if you like problem/puzzle solving games mixed in with some exploratory horror and mystery, then I would recommend this game for you. If you don't, well, you probably won't enjoy playing it.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2012
												Parts of Anna, I flat out love. However, Anna gets a lot of things wrong. ****You have to register an account with Kalypso just to play this single-player, offline game. ♥♥♥♥ you, Kalypso! It's like Ubisofts ultra fail DRM that does NOTHING to combat piracy, but does ♥♥♥♥ their paying customers over.****  It is very poorly optimized and the very modest graphics tax my video card as bad as Battlefield 3. The shadows moving on the walls look like dark, dancing squares. An average computer from five years ago should have had no problem generating the grpahics, if the game was coded properly. Also, the inventory usage is ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Combining items and even just getting a description of an item kicks you out of inventory and you have to go back again. Also, the story is a bit of a muddled mess. From what I gathered, the dude you play as killed a bunch of people because he's a stupid crazy ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥. Now that I'm done ♥♥♥♥♥ing about the crap, Anna absolutely NAILS the proper tone for a horror adventure game. There is no dying in the game, but it was very unsettling and there are some decent scares. It was good enough that I did make sure to only play it at night in the dark with headphones on. I completely love these types of spooky ghost story point and clicks. Anna took around 5 hours finish. I am eagerly anticipating the developers next game. This game like a nice juicy steak garnished with turds. If you like horror point and clicks, definitely get Anna when it's on sale.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 5, 2015
												Short: Strange game, well worth the cost.Long: Spooky with the odd very nicely done jump scare. Not that many jump scares, which is nice, otherwise they don't work that well :) One or two were (for me anyway) genuinely unnerving. On the Extended version though, after a certain point the spooky factor gives way to pure puzzle solving intrigue, and some of what should be "spooky" actually becomes quite comforting. (This may be a measure of insanity after playing the game for hours).Some of the puzzle solving is a case of "how on earth was I supposed to figure that out?", especially when it comes to trying to unlock all the achievements, but I'd still suggest getting as far as you can with it before interweb searching past a bit where you're stuck.An odd game. Somehow manages to maintain a replay value which is rare. For best results. Play at night, on your own, preferably in winter with a storm outside.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 7, 2013
												Anna was a very short, yet enjoyable game. The story was very well written and the atmosphere and soundtrack were phenomenal. It is rare to find a game with a story so captivating that whenever you are away from it, all you can do is think about what will happen next. It took me about 6 hours to beat Anna and I unlocked one of eight possible endings. As for the horror aspect of the game - Anna will make you jump a quite few times - the scenes were well thought out and weren't cheesy like any of the FEAR games. Anna incorperates a 'Sanity Meter' similar to that of Eternal Darkness on Gamecube, the more unnerving images that your character sees/experiences the more sanity is drained from the meter, resulting in more horrific images. If the Sanity meter is depeleted the game will end. You can replenish Sanity by completeing various puzzles throughout the game. Just a heads-up, puzzles range in difficulty from Easy to "♥♥♥♥ this, I'm looking up a walkthrough". Anna was an ejoyable gaming experience and well worth the cost of admission, give it a shot.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												After getting bored with playing titles that I would consider as "AAA", I tried to give Anna a try. I've actually played this game several times, but only solving a few puzzles and never entering the house. Once you get pass that, that's where the thrill begins.Goosebumps! Something I haven't had in a game for a while. Yes, it's the same atmosphere you'll get when if you played Silent Hill for the first time on the PS1. There's no combat action though, and it mostly involves solving puzzles and reading journals. Maybe doing some trial and errors just to see how something would work. This game requires some brains to play.I'm playing this game on its maximum settings and the environment is truly fantastic. The background music and sound effects add to the eerie atmosphere as you uncover the truth about who Anna is.It's possible to save at almost any point in the game. So this can be something that you play for 10 minutes, take a break, then come back to later.The only caveat in this game is it doesn't have controller support. It's very much made only to be played on a PC.  There's also the annoying login/registration screen that you need to deal with before starting the game. What gives? I already bought the game! Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a scare.

content:
Posted: July 24, 2013
												This is definitely worth a purchase for the folks who like a good constipation aid. Well above Amnesia on the "Curl up and cry softly in a corner" category.The story is pretty interesting depending on which ending you actually get. And getting the "good" (and I use 'good' in the loosest possible way) requires a lot of work.The puzzles you're required to solve in order to progress are anything from simple to "I've been stuck in this room for 7 ♥♥♥♥ing hours, dammit...". Not to say they aren't solveable, they just require a lot of searching and gathering of items. And downright odd combinations of items. Advice? Read every single book you find carefully.On top of that, the puzzles are made all the more tricky when you're in a constant state of fear that when you turn around next, something will be stood right behind you. Don't get me wrong, there's no 'health', per se, but you have an Amnesia-style sanity meter. Which depletes because of randomly occuring "events". Each and everyone pretty damn creepy.Overall, terrifying game but pretty damn good. Worth the purchase.P.S. I now ♥♥♥♥ing hate wooden mannequins.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 30, 2012
												This is an interesting game. On the surface it seems like an indie company's exposition, but this game offers a refreshing horror experience. Instead of making looking at ghosts the main mechanic (a la Fatal Frame), this game lures you into sense of security, realizing that what you see is frightening only after the image has seeped into your mind. Let me be clear, the controls are awkward and the graphics do not have the polish of a big title; Anna makes up for it in character and some good scares. Just when you think it's safe to look...she looks back.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												I wasn't expecting much from Anna and what I got was a surprisingly strong Myst-style adventure game with a heavy atmosphere and strong presentation.  It's not often a game can deeply rattle me but Anna has some legitimate scares and freakout moments by smartly employing insanity effects you often can't predict and organically using events that happen behind you.  My largest complaint is that the puzzles can be pretty obtuse -- not because they're actually difficult but the darkness of the game and detailed levels make it easy to skip things you wish you had noticed.  This aside, play the extended edition version of the game with a pair of headphones and immerse yourself in a fantastic 3-4 hour experience any fan of adventure and horror games will love.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2012
												A great concept marred by bitterly pityful execution.What starts out to be a promising logical puzzle horror adventure game turns out to be a completely irrational, illogical set of clicks and attempts by the player to try to guess what the developers intended to happen with little or no feedback at all. Even the in-game hints system is vague at best.The controls for inventory and using items is very annoying and lacks fluidity. The forced walking speed is an annoyance, especially when there is a fair amount of backtracking throughout the game involved.You also can not describe this title as a horror survival either, as its not possible to die.Some nice touches of horror brushing through the gameplay but very weak and suspense is not sustained properly in-game, which causes the scares to be cheap jumps rather than actual in-your-head horror. Not very obvious but there are 3 different endings which is always a nice touch to implement into any game.I'm a fan of this genre so its great to see games like this get developed and out into the commercial world, especially by independant developers but if unpolished titles like this were released out often the genre would be soon dead and forgotten.Worth a couple of quid in the sale and you have an interest in horror type games, but avoid paying full whack.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												This game is very tricky to recommend, but I feel it's worth a shot for anyone who misses the OLD discovery games. I've been getting flashbacks to the unbridled madness of titles like Lighthouse, and am not sure how I feel about that.Thus far it took me most of half an hour just to get inside, because I was admiring the scenery and completely failing to find the item I needed to advance the entry puzzle...after that I have fled just to see what happens, then later was kicked out of the house. (Two endings down!)Puzzle difficulty and exploration difficulty is all over the place, the books help a bit but this is definitely an indie game and the built-in help is there for a reason. I really wish the inserted voices were better, they are bordeline tolerable but a major chance of adding atmosphere was lost there. There is some bad english in places, but it doesn't smell like a fanfic or amateur translation...the most critical story elements got the extra polish they needed and are a delight to read.In closing I would say that while the game is not very player-driven so much as event-driven, time management and NOT INVESTIGATING STRANGE NOISES are a big priority for me in starting my next run. It seems a reasonable amount of sanity damage may be avoided by not triggering/witnessing supernatural events.At this rate I am willing to start fresh and attempt to beat it cleanly two more times, then it's time for shameless abuse of outside help.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												I wasn't expecting much from Anna and what I got was a surprisingly strong Myst-style adventure game with a heavy atmosphere and strong presentation.  It's not often a game can deeply rattle me but Anna has some legitimate scares and freakout moments by smartly employing insanity effects you often can't predict and organically using events that happen behind you.  My largest complaint is that the puzzles can be pretty obtuse -- not because they're actually difficult but the darkness of the game and detailed levels make it easy to skip things you wish you had noticed.  This aside, play the extended edition version of the game with a pair of headphones and immerse yourself in a fantastic 3-4 hour experience any fan of adventure and horror games will love.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
												This game is very tricky to recommend, but I feel it's worth a shot for anyone who misses the OLD discovery games. I've been getting flashbacks to the unbridled madness of titles like Lighthouse, and am not sure how I feel about that.Thus far it took me most of half an hour just to get inside, because I was admiring the scenery and completely failing to find the item I needed to advance the entry puzzle...after that I have fled just to see what happens, then later was kicked out of the house. (Two endings down!)Puzzle difficulty and exploration difficulty is all over the place, the books help a bit but this is definitely an indie game and the built-in help is there for a reason. I really wish the inserted voices were better, they are bordeline tolerable but a major chance of adding atmosphere was lost there. There is some bad english in places, but it doesn't smell like a fanfic or amateur translation...the most critical story elements got the extra polish they needed and are a delight to read.In closing I would say that while the game is not very player-driven so much as event-driven, time management and NOT INVESTIGATING STRANGE NOISES are a big priority for me in starting my next run. It seems a reasonable amount of sanity damage may be avoided by not triggering/witnessing supernatural events.At this rate I am willing to start fresh and attempt to beat it cleanly two more times, then it's time for shameless abuse of outside help.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
												This game is amazing! Once I started this game, I didn't stop until I had finished, it was that good!It takes a little while at the start to get into what you have to do, but once you get into the sawmill, that's when it starts to get interesting and really fun!The puzzles are so fun to complete, but admittedly are sometimes irritating when you can't find an item! But once you finish each puzzle, it starts off a new motion, the next part of the story.The story is very well presented. The further you get into the story the more you start questioning everything. Nothing is as it seems.It's a rather creepy game and has some parts that make you jump. The amount of times I screamed during the game was ridiculous! By the end you think every little thing you do is going to cause something to jump out at you!It also has different pathways to choose and different endings based on what you choose to do during the game, so you can play the game multiple times and get different results (and different achievements) everytime!I had my reservations about buying this game due to all of the bad reviews, but I'm so so glad I bought it anyway! This game is perfect for those who love puzzle games and creepy/weird/disturbing stories with a plot twist that you don't see coming!

												I enjpyed this game a great deal, but I'll readily admit that it's likely going to be an acquired taste.  The in-game lighting can make it difficult to locate some crucial quest items and even with the available online help, required tasks may still be pretty esoteric at times.  That said, the game drips with atmosphere, looks pretty, and has a great musical score.  The multiple endings are also a nice incentive to replay the game to unlock more of the interesting in-game lore.  If you can stomach its quirks, Anna is a decent way to kill a few hours here and there.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2012
												A great concept marred by bitterly pityful execution.What starts out to be a promising logical puzzle horror adventure game turns out to be a completely irrational, illogical set of clicks and attempts by the player to try to guess what the developers intended to happen with little or no feedback at all. Even the in-game hints system is vague at best.The controls for inventory and using items is very annoying and lacks fluidity. The forced walking speed is an annoyance, especially when there is a fair amount of backtracking throughout the game involved.You also can not describe this title as a horror survival either, as its not possible to die.Some nice touches of horror brushing through the gameplay but very weak and suspense is not sustained properly in-game, which causes the scares to be cheap jumps rather than actual in-your-head horror. Not very obvious but there are 3 different endings which is always a nice touch to implement into any game.I'm a fan of this genre so its great to see games like this get developed and out into the commercial world, especially by independant developers but if unpolished titles like this were released out often the genre would be soon dead and forgotten.Worth a couple of quid in the sale and you have an interest in horror type games, but avoid paying full whack.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 16, 2013
												Anna is a game to reckoned with.  You want scary? This is it.  You want disturbing? This is it.  You want a dark storyline devling into the darkest corners of the world?  This is it.  This game is fairly well done, although the games interface is lacking, it makes up for that by scaring the s*** out of you.  Great storyline, borderline Satanic, and very, very interesting.  UPDATE:  Since the Extended Edition update I have had about 5 more hours of gameplay than my initial review above and I thought it prudent to expand on what I was saying considering the additions made to the game since then.  The Extended Edition update truly was an update and added genuine content and changes to the game.  The graphics were updated and the game looks more beautiful than ever.  The sound was revamped just a little bit, which is a ever welcome update.  They also modified the actual gameplay itself, smoothing out the previously clunky controls and making it overall easier to handle.  The actual game area itself has been altered just a little bit, moving things around in the game world as well as adding even more possible endings to a grand total of 8 different ending available.  The UI is a little iffy, but with the new controls and new graphics and the story line itself, the game really makes up for it shortcomings in other areas.  Still a solid 9/10.

content:
Posted: February 1, 2015
												After getting bored with playing titles that I would consider as "AAA", I tried to give Anna a try. I've actually played this game several times, but only solving a few puzzles and never entering the house. Once you get pass that, that's where the thrill begins.Goosebumps! Something I haven't had in a game for a while. Yes, it's the same atmosphere you'll get when if you played Silent Hill for the first time on the PS1. There's no combat action though, and it mostly involves solving puzzles and reading journals. Maybe doing some trial and errors just to see how something would work. This game requires some brains to play.I'm playing this game on its maximum settings and the environment is truly fantastic. The background music and sound effects add to the eerie atmosphere as you uncover the truth about who Anna is.It's possible to save at almost any point in the game. So this can be something that you play for 10 minutes, take a break, then come back to later.The only caveat in this game is it doesn't have controller support. It's very much made only to be played on a PC.  There's also the annoying login/registration screen that you need to deal with before starting the game. What gives? I already bought the game! Overall, I highly recommend this game to anyone looking for a scare.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 7, 2013
												Anna was a very short, yet enjoyable game. The story was very well written and the atmosphere and soundtrack were phenomenal. It is rare to find a game with a story so captivating that whenever you are away from it, all you can do is think about what will happen next. It took me about 6 hours to beat Anna and I unlocked one of eight possible endings. As for the horror aspect of the game - Anna will make you jump a quite few times - the scenes were well thought out and weren't cheesy like any of the FEAR games. Anna incorperates a 'Sanity Meter' similar to that of Eternal Darkness on Gamecube, the more unnerving images that your character sees/experiences the more sanity is drained from the meter, resulting in more horrific images. If the Sanity meter is depeleted the game will end. You can replenish Sanity by completeing various puzzles throughout the game. Just a heads-up, puzzles range in difficulty from Easy to "♥♥♥♥ this, I'm looking up a walkthrough". Anna was an ejoyable gaming experience and well worth the cost of admission, give it a shot.

												A fun game if you enjoy exploration and story telling with a creepy atmosphere. My only complaint is that after a certain point in the game, you can no longer casually explore without your "panic meter" (that's what I keep calling it) filling up and eventually getting you killed. Overall, I found the music to be really relaxing and beautiful, the atmosphere often creepy (this is a good thing!), and the story was decently satisfying in the end despite really hustling through parts halfway through (see above). If you're a horror fan, I think this game is worth your time and money!

												There's alot not to like about this game. It uses the kalypso DRM, which annoys me, especially when it's already on top of steam's... so if you misplace your steam OR kalypso login, you won't be able to play. The game is kinda clunky an unclear in spots. And you can't skip the intro scene, and it's not especially exciting your later times through the game, if you want to get all the endings. content:
Posted: May 25, 2016
												Time to beat: under 5 hoursPlayed with keyboard and mouse. Easy to control.Bugs: none that i encountered.Story: meh. Motionsickness factor: I felt sick to some degree. Probably from the entire game being enclosed in a small house. :XFear: the game was creepy. Ambient sounds were alright. No jump scares at all, just things suddenly there that weren't there before...which at times took me by surprise. This is NOT an Amnesia-type game. It's not even action. It's more narrative.This game has MULTIPLE endings. I only did 2. So with 8 different possible endings, I suppose this game might have replay value. I do not feel compelled to complete all 8.I needed to consult a walk through on several occasions. Some things just aren't very clear on how to proceed with the tasks. (example, the 'Intuition' icons at the top of the inventory screen, I had NO IDEA what they were for. I thought they were chapter markers.) I suppose if I took the time to read all the 'documents' and 'books' in the game, perhaps there would have been some indication or hint on the tasks, but the fonts used were bloody awful to read, sooooo nope.SO...would I recommend this game? I think I would say yes, but maaaaybe get it on sale and DON'T expect this game to be full of action and screams. It's really just slow paced and head-scratching.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 7, 2016
												Anna is... weird. But a pretty fun kind of weird. A bit slow at parts, but enjoyable on the whole.The key things to bring along when playing Anna are observation and inference. There are a lot of puzzles whose required solutions are fairly subtly hidden, so you'll need to keep an eye out for objects and/or connections between things you've seen or found most of the time. This is made that much more important by how Anna takes a lot of different occult material and remixes it into its own pocket mythos, making any supernatural points of reference the player may have a bit less useful here.Speaking of remixes, if you've played the non-Extended edition before, there are some new and remixed puzzles from the original version, so keep that in mind. Solutions have changed slightly, or at least, it felt as such. To be fair, it'd been a while since I finished Anna originally, so it could just be failures on my memory's part.Despite its occasional drifts into the obtuse, Anna - Extended Edition is a fun, sometimes frustrating romp through lingering dread and ambient menace. The encapsulated nature of the story presents something different from most rehashed horror trope-fests and is worth trying, if only to get your brainmeats flexing for a bit.If you want a taste of the game, here's a -really- old clip of me exploring the starting area in the original version. 


YouTube™ Video: IndiVer - Anna (Groupees' Bundle Of The Damned)

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 12, 2014
												As a person who has always been afraid of horror games, this game was quite the catch I needed to help me overcome that fear. There are no monsters like Amnesia or other horror games. It is purely puzzle-driven, with some psychological fear factors added into it. The scenery is beautiful, the music is wonderful as well, though at times it seems like it does not fit the atmosphere of the game. However, I think with how soft, and beautiful, the music is, adds to the atmosphere of the overall game.Now, a couple of things I did not really like about this game. It felt WAY too short... Maybe even a little rushed at some parts. I feel there could be so much more done to this to help aid the story along and to add more to it. I also hated some of the puzzles. I had no idea what to do for some of them, and eventually had to give in and look up a guide. There are a couple of puzzles that give hints, but other than that, nothing. The controls are rather easy to remember. The inventory is another issue that I had. There were some items that were SO pointless to have that the end of the game, and even throughout the game. Aside from the few cons and issues I had with this game, it definitely terrified me to play the first couple of times. I have played through it numerous times for different friends, all which have liked the ctual story. Personally, I would have to give this game a 7.5/10. There were some things that could be improved, but overall I think it was a very interesting, very plot-twisting game.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2013
												Anna was a very short, yet enjoyable game. The story was very well written and the atmosphere and soundtrack were phenomenal. It is rare to find a game with a story so captivating that whenever you are away from it, all you can do is think about what will happen next. It took me about 6 hours to beat Anna and I unlocked one of eight possible endings. As for the horror aspect of the game - Anna will make you jump a quite few times - the scenes were well thought out and weren't cheesy like any of the FEAR games. Anna incorperates a 'Sanity Meter' similar to that of Eternal Darkness on Gamecube, the more unnerving images that your character sees/experiences the more sanity is drained from the meter, resulting in more horrific images. If the Sanity meter is depeleted the game will end. You can replenish Sanity by completeing various puzzles throughout the game. Just a heads-up, puzzles range in difficulty from Easy to "♥♥♥♥ this, I'm looking up a walkthrough". Anna was an ejoyable gaming experience and well worth the cost of admission, give it a shot.

Posted: January 12, 2015
												This game confused me at first, until i found out that I can inspect items for details  by right clicking them I couldnt figure out why things were working when randomly clicking made it work.  Learning that the things at the top of the page (intuitions) can be combined to put the story together also helped in figuring things out.  I have played it for 2 days and gotten 5 out of 8 endings and want to play it again to get them all and see what I missed. This game has just the right amount of creepy, a story that was interesting enough that even when i had figured it out I wanted to know the details and nothing was spoiled, and a lot of small details that if you are looking will surprise you.Turning mouse sensitivity down in the game helped a ton with sanity.  ;)

content:
Posted: November 28, 2012
												Athmospheric puzzel game that takes the player into a mysterioussaw-mill in a middle of nowhere, no way out but to push inside the buildingin search for anwsers to this occuring dream and the women named Anna.Graphics is wonderful and nice to look at when particular effects take place.The feel of the game is mysterious and slightly scary, with weird things happeningaround you, accompanied by a well done music by the Chantry band.The puzzel elements are overly challenging, the game not giving any general hints(unless you wait for 5-10 min for the games option to kick in)and some of logics behind them escapes from general players mind.(Use a acorn on a eye to burn it so it may unlock a door.....oooookay...)Story in the game is intriquing and can pull the player to wonder the mysterythat happened here, althou that is generally spoiled more or less once the1st strange drawings appear on the walls.Still, kept me going just to see what´s happening and the ending,kinda of a let down, was still interesting.Suitable for more old school puzzel gamers (Sierra moon-logic ahoy!),and not really worth it´s price as it currently is.4/10

content:
Posted: December 19, 2016
												I'd recommend this if you enjoy puzzle games. If you've ever been to an escape room kind of thing in real life then you'll love this game. You might want to get a couple of friends over or at least have a guide you can refer to when you get stuck because it's a pretty hard game. A lot of things are easy to miss and still essential to being able to progress further.The controls feel wonky at times and the game can be buggy but then again it was made by kalypso (the same people who made tropico). The way you use items and handle your inventory is probably the most uncomfortable part. Your character can't jump or run but you can crouch with C. The way you open doors feels kinda like Frictional Games, but you can't right click to just perform an action and need to drag instead. The game also makes you log in to kalypso's platform so I always had to launch it in windowed mode and then alt+enter after logging in so it wouldn't crash. It's a great game but it could have been way better.
